G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as this matter arises in tort, and the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Norfolk County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Norfolk County.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award pre- and post-judgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

Estes v. Tower Associates, 396 Mass. 245.proposition: Estes v. Tower Associates, 396 Mass. 245 (1985) (Defendant liable for unsafe conditions known or reasonably discoverable).

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007) (constructive notice and reasonable care).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses constructive notice and reasonable care in the premises-liability context. It explains the traditional constructive-notice requirement and then adopts the mode-of-operation approach, under which the store’s knowledge of risks inherent in its self-service operation can satisfy the notice element, while still requiring the plaintiff to prove the defendant failed to take reasonable precautions. Thus, the case is properly cited for principles of constructive notice (as modified by mode of operation) and reasonable care in a self-service store setting.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the adoption of the mode of operation approach will not modify the general rule governing premises liability requiring a plaintiff to prove that an owner had either actual or constructive notice of an unsafe condition on the premises. However, if a plaintiff proves that an unsafe condition on an owner’s premises exists that was reasonably foreseeable, resulting from an owner’s self-service business or mode of operation, and the plaintiff slips as a result of the unsafe condition, the plaintiff will satisfy the notice requirement… [and] whether the owner took all necessary reasonable precautions commensurate with the risks….”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973) (actual or constructive knowledge of dangers).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the requirement that a possessor of premises must act on dangers of which it knows or ought to know, i.e., actual or constructive knowledge. The court explains that a plaintiff may prove negligence either by showing the defendant caused the condition, had actual knowledge of it, or that it existed long enough that the defendant should have known of it, and then applies that standard to the facts. Thus, the case is appropriately cited for the actual/constructive knowledge principle in premises liability.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises…in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers…of which the defendant knows or ought to know.… [The plaintiff] may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance.… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present…for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

Correia v. New Bedford Gas & Edison Ligh.raw_text: Correia v. New Bedford Gas & Edison Light Co., 333 Mass. 222 (1955)
Correia v. New Bedford Gas & Edison Ligh.proposition: Correia v. New Bedford Gas & Edison Light Co., 333 Mass. 222 (1955) (duty to warn of hazards).
Correia v. New Bedford Gas & Edison Ligh.support_reasoning: The opinion is a premises-liability slip-and-fall case focused on obvious vs. hidden defects and assumption of risk, not on a storeowner’s affirmative duty to warn of hazards. The court discusses that an invitee cannot recover for injuries caused by obvious, permanent conditions, but it does not analyze, articulate, or apply any distinct rule about a duty to warn of hazards. Using this case as authority specifically for a “duty to warn of hazards” proposition is therefore inaccurate or, at best, highly indirect.
Correia v. New Bedford Gas & Edison Ligh.relevant_excerpt: "If the conditions are perfectly obvious to a person of ordinary intelligence she can’t complain if she is injured by those conditions, if they were of a permanent nature. A person assumes the risk of being injured by conditions of a permanent nature if they are perfectly obvious, if he uses his intelligence and senses. If anything in the way of a hidden defect makes the place dangerous, the person injured by it isn’t bound by the fact that it was there."

Zarilli v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. C.raw_text: Zarilli v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co., 357 Mass. 657 (1970)
Zarilli v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. C.proposition: Zarilli v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co., 357 Mass. 657 (1970) (liability for injury resulting from unreasonable delay in hazard cleanup).
Zarilli v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. C.case_name: Manganaro Drywall, Inc. v. Penn-Simon Construction Co.
Zarilli v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. C.support_reasoning: The opinion is a contract and suretyship dispute about the enforceability of a retroactive interest provision and whether it is unconscionable or a penalty. It does not involve tort liability, personal injury, hazardous conditions, or delay in cleanup of any hazard. Therefore it does not address, much less establish, any rule about liability for injury resulting from unreasonable delay in hazard cleanup.
Zarilli v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. C.relevant_excerpt: “The only question of law thus presented to the trial court was whether the provision of the contract for retroactive interest on the entire sum of $78,117.36 in the event of the defendant’s failure to pay any instalment when due was ‘unconscionable and void as contrary to public policy.’ … This was not an unconscionable potential price to be paid by the defendant in return for the concessions made by the plaintiff.”

Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.raw_text: Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837 (1987)
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.proposition: Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837 (1987) (premises liability for failing to warn of obvious or hidden dangers).
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.support_reasoning: The concurring opinion squarely addresses premises liability in the context of a gas station and discusses the landowner’s duty (or lack thereof) to warn customers about risks on the premises. It expressly states that the risk of injury from negligent operation of other vehicles on a self-service station’s premises is “inherent and obvious” and that there is “no duty to warn” of such a danger, thereby supporting the general proposition about premises liability and the duty to warn of obvious or hidden dangers (here, finding no duty for an obvious one).
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010) (affirming duty to address foreseeable hazards).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The court expressly abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and replaces it with the general premises-liability duty of reasonable care for all hazards, including snow and ice. In doing so, it grounds liability in whether the owner acted as a reasonable person in light of foreseeable risks and the probability and seriousness of harm, which is effectively an affirmation of a duty to address foreseeable hazards on the premises.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuset.raw_text: Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachusetts, Inc., 418 Mass. 590 (1994)
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuset.proposition: Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachusetts, Inc., 418 Mass. 590 (1994) (reasonable duty of care for premises liability).
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuset.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses and applies the general “reasonable duty of care” standard for premises liability, quoting and relying on Mounsey and Toubiana. While the case ultimately finds no breach (because there was insufficient evidence of actual or constructive notice of the ice), it clearly reaffirms that a landowner owes a duty to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances. Thus, it is appropriate authority for the general reasonable-care duty standard in premises liability, even though the plaintiff lost on its application here.
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Massachuset.relevant_excerpt: “The law imposes on a property owner ‘a duty to maintain his property “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.”’ Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 88 (1988), quoting Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973). As the defendant observes, however, a defendant in a premises liability case is ‘not obliged to supply a place of maximum safety, but only one which would be safe to a person who exercises such minimum care as the circumstances reasonably indicate.’”
